posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked:
We have a limelight 3G (with a 4 on the way) and due to where the reef april tags are, we are seeing a lot of ambiguity flipping. We are trying to reduce the height of our limelight as much as possible to prevent this, making its height under the april tag, but I’m worried it will still be an issue.

Originally when tuning our limelights for april tags, we followed this guide: Tracking AprilTags | Limelight Documentation

But then when faced with the ambiguity flipping, I tried messing around with settings and realized that seemingly random things, such as increasing the exposure (a lot), helped reduce flipping.

Any other advice for how to improve this?
Are you using Megatag 1? If so, you should really switch to Megatag 2. It’ll probably fix your issue.

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked: This question is for MT1 yes, but we also use MT2. From our testing though, even at slower rotational speeds MT2 becomes inaccurate so hence us also wanting to use MT1.

posts.name: Adithya Anand
posts.cooked: The new updates with NetworkTables 4 seemed to reduce the inaccuracy with MT2, at least for us. Have you tried these at all?

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked: We are just using LimelightHelpers.SetRobotOrientation() Does this not use the newest network tables?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: IIRC there is a gyro latency slider on the LL dashboard. Soon I’ll be figuring out what that does; maybe it will help you.
It depends on the LL OS release you’re using. IIRC 2025 and above uses NT4. Whereas older releases use NT3.

posts.name: Edan Liahovetsky
posts.cooked: What parameters are you passing into setRobotOrientation? From some quick tests, passing in chassis’s speeds along with the yaw should help reduce error during high rotational speeds. The latency GUI slider is also a nice feature. MT2 does provide pose estimates with less ambiguity than MT1 and an aggressive STDDev rotational constant gain could help mitigate the effects of robot rotational velocity.

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked: We are passing in the yaw and yaw speed, and using the latency slider. We just generally found MT2 wasn’t very reliable while rotating faster than like 45 degrees a second, which is really slow lol

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Traptricker:

45 degrees a second

I’ve looked at other teams’ filtering (a very risky endeavor) and see numbers like 100 or 200 and 3 (and of course the 720) - so some are a far cry from the LL recommended 720. Have to guess so not 100% sure of the units of these numbers but others’ experience appear somewhat similar to yours.

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked: I agree its weird, because last year we had 180 deg/s working really well. I think we will probably look back into it, especially once we get the LL4.
Why are you passing in yaw speed? The field is marked as optional… we don’t pass it in and it works great. Maybe try not setting it?

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked: Really? I guess we can try it. Is your MT2 position while rotating reliable?

Crafter:

Why are you passing in yaw speed?

There’s no reason not to send more information to the limelight if it could help our pose estimation, no?

I did not notice a difference while testing with and without that parameter passed in.
Yeah it works great! No complaints from us!

You could be passing it in wrong (e.g wrong units) or worse, the parameter is bugged on the LL side. It isn’t documented super clearly. It may explain why you can only rotate so fast without the pose being wrong. If you’re using a NavX, yaw rate is bugged and you shouldn’t use it, for us the function returned seemingly random numbers ranging all the way up to a couple million degrees per second.

Crafter:

If you’re using a NavX, yaw rate is bugged and you shouldn’t use it, for us the function returned seemingly random numbers ranging all the way up to a couple million degrees per second.

This is concerning Maybe I’m just blind…

posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked: That is good to know… we are using a NavX lol
